text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

RANJAY GULATI: So the
first T is Talent.

At one level, you might say
there's a market for talent.

And everybody has all
the same information.
They all go out and scout it.

And it's a pretty
efficient market.

But there seems to be something
about smelling and sniffing
out a great player.

And that sniffing
out is where you

are saying you can make somebody
way better than they actually
are.

You see the potential
in them, not just what
they've accomplished.

The market price is
our accomplishment.

So if you see an ace pitcher,
there's a bidding war going on.

You're going to pay a
market or above market

rates depending on how many
people want that player.

But it's about sniffing out
talent that nobody else sees.

And that's seeing
potential in talent.

If you think about Bobby
Cox and the Atlanta Braves,

so one of the first
things Bobby Cox does

is he teams up with the head
of personnel, Paul Schneider,

and says, we're going to
revamp how we find players.

And right on their
opportunity spaces,

Todd Van Poppel, one
of the ace pitchers.
And he passes on him, saying no.

And they find this
unknown, Chipper Jones.
And the rest is history.

They go on to win 14 division
titles over the next 14 years.

Extraordinary outcome, all
driven by Bobby's ability
to smell out talent.

We can look at Pete Carroll, the
coach of the Seattle Seahawks,

taking Russell Wilson when
nobody else wants him.

So here in New England, we have
Tom Brady, who was way down,
I think, 199 on the pick.

But they saw something in
him and gave him a chance.

They see potential where
others might not see potential.

It's not that can
this person be better?
It's can I make them better?

Do I see the
opportunity that I feel

I have the confidence that
I can take this person
and make them great?

It's their ability to say,
this person will really

fit my organization, will
really resonate with me,

and I see the opportunity
to take this person where
I don't think others can.

It's not just hiring
individual players.

Sir Alex Ferguson, the former
coach of Manchester United,

always said, "I'm not
here to build a team.
I'm not here to win a season.

I'm here to build
a winning club."
So I have a time horizon.

I want to see the chemistry
among the players,

that they work well
together as a team.

How do I groom players early,
get them early in soccer?

You see a lot of that, getting
players very, very early,

when they're very
young, grooming them,

but also making sure
that they are part
of the chemistry of the team.

Talent really can be
understood at three levels.

The first level is, what are
you capable of doing today?
Are you talented today?

Have you worked yourself to
be an immediate contributor
to our collective effort?

What are you
working in the door?

The second piece of talent
is, what's your potential?
How much further can you go?
And are you willing to go?

Some people are
talented players,
don't want to push any further.
They don't have the work ethic.

They don't have the oomph in
them to want to get better.

Related to that is,
can I as a coach

connect with you such that I can
help you unlock that potential?

The third layer is, what
about you and the team?

Are you going to really
gel with the team?

Are we going to be able
to work well and achieve
our potential as a collective?

And how well would you
connect with the team?

So let's apply this to
the business context.

Absolutely, I think what ends
up happening is who do we hire?

We hire people on
accomplishment, not so much
on potential.

It's really hard
to gauge potential.

We miss out on this idea
that we can shape and develop

people and help them live
up to their potential,

finding those
diamonds in the rough.

And then the last part
is, to what extent

are they going to be
able to fit our culture,
they're going to fit our team?

Are they a team player or
an individual contributor?

So I think it's important
to understand and think

about talent in these
three different layers,

the same way in sports and
the same way in business.
